Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Visibility as a Wireless Sensor Network Design Principle

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
Tiny, embedded computers will collect real-time data on our homes, our cities, and our planet. Collecting and processing rich streams of sensor data will transform public health, medicine, natural resource management, science, engineering, and disaster response. But today, despite years of research and engineering, these sensor networks often fail to meet their performance goals. Data yields are low; networks last weeks, rather than months; long downtimes are common.

Professor Levis proposes a long-term agenda of research and education to improve the robustness, manageability, and scalability of low-power wireless sensing systems. The dominant design principle behind this agenda is network visibility. Described colloquially, visibility measures a user?s ability to identify the cause of a network event, such as a packet drop. We propose to research how to make networks more visible.

The research agenda is grounded in the exploration, development, and evaluation of the Mote Network
(MNet) architecture, an open-source protocol suite and toolkit for sensor network application development and deployment. The protocol suite will include existing dominant protocols redesigned for improved visibility as well as novel protocols whose designs maximizes visibility. Our principal goal is to make long-lived sensornets significantly simpler to deploy and maintain. Our second goal is to apply our lessons learned to wireless meshes more generally.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project researched how to make it easier to build networks of tiny, battery-powered, networked computers -- the Internet of Things. The research focused on low-power wireless communication because it is often the most difficult and challenging part of building these networks. The research had three major outcomes:

  1. It conducted a deep scientific study of how low-power wireless links behave and defined new metrics that precisely measure this behavior. This found that many assumptions made by network designers were not true in practice, explaining why many systems seemed to work well in testing but not well once deployed or used in real environments.
  2. Based on the scientific study, it researched and defined a new networking protocol called the Collection Tree Protocol (CTP). CTP enables a large network of tiny, low-power wireless devices to build a robust and efficient mesh to a "root" in the network (typically a router or other gateway to the wider Internet). This mesh allows the network to deliver data to the root from nodes that are many hops away. CTP's tremendous success led it to become the core building block of RFC6550, the Internet standard for connecting the Internet of Things to the wider Internet.
  3. It demonstrated the first prototypes of full duplex wireless radios. Before this grant, all wireless protocols and communication systems generally assumed it was impossible for a device to simultaneously transmit and receive at the same time on the same frequency band. This is because the transmitted signal is millions to billions times stronger than what the radio might want to receive: it is like trying to hear a whisper from across the room while shouting. Research funded by this grant built and demonstrated the first full duplex wireless radios -- radios that can simultaneously transmit and receive on the same frequency band. The results of this research are now being considered for inclusion as future extensions of LTE and WiFi.
